title: Mining Text Snippets for Images on the Web
segmentation: Good morning everyone.

I'm going to be talking about mining text inputs for images on the web and this basically interlinking images and text and this joint work with a number of collaborators both in research and also in the product group.

So there's a lot of work and traditional image to text of coming from the computer vision literature where the goal is to understand the visual pixels in the image and then translate that into a textual form.
So for this example here on Albert Einstein, we would be looking at as recognizing that this is Albert Einstein and that possibly that is sticking out his tongue.
OK, and then the text would be Albert Einstein sticking out this time, so that's how traditional image text has been looked at.
And what we want to do instead in this work is understand what people say when they use this image on the web.
Get us.
So for instance, the same image when people use this image on the web to write something about Einstein.
One of the things they bring up is.
What is the backdrop behind this picture?
When was this picture taken, for instance?
So this is more interesting for users when they see these images than to say that Albert Einstein is sticking out his tongue.
And we want to be able to do this for every image on the web.
So let me start off by giving you some more examples.
This is a classic example of photo from Maldives.
When you talk about tourism in Maldives and what other people have also used this image to talk about monsoon season in Maldives.
Interestingly they have two months and seasons.
If you're from India you'll know that there's one in one season.
This is a rainy season.
In India and here in Maltese you got two of those OK, another one people talk about is how?
What's the what's the area in Maldives?
Here's another example of this famous guitarist, Jim Senchal Hendrix, who had a great influence on rock music.
OK so I.

But we were thinking, what can you?
What are the applications behind this right?
And so we did a lot of.
User studies both understanding how people use image search.
Looking at the browse trials, what people do when they are when they start off an image search and then what do they do right after that right?
You can look at the entire browse trails.
We also had a lot of focus studies where we brought in people to see what do they do on image search.
So 22 main things came out in this entire studies that we have done over almost a year.
One is that people like to look for like interesting information around that image.
They want to say what is interesting about this image?
Why?
Why is this particular image versus something else for the same search query?
And also they want pointers to related image, interesting images related in terms of both US semantics and also visual and sometimes more in terms of semantics.

And if you look at today Google search image Search or Bing image search you will see that sometimes when you start out with the search query you also get category information and so you're looking at a lot of dogs you may have like pets as another category.
You suggested cats and so on, right?
Or suggested pets.
These are all sort of showing that people are actually interested in finding related images while they're on a search query, and most of the experience on image search has been about browsing.
Unlike web search where you are looking for information and was just seeking that particular information.
OK, so so having having this as a promise we said there could be an experience that can build around images.
That's about browsing.

So how do we mind for the snippets?
So there are two main key insights that we have under algorithm is based on these two key insights.

One is redundancy if an image is interesting, people use that image over and over again on the web, so you can actually mind for these images on the web and they have multiple web pages that carry those images.
Second one is the diversity of the context and they use the same image to talk about different things.
So for instance we go back to the small these examples that I was telling you before.
People use the same photo to talk about tourism and all these are the monsoon season.
Maltese and so on.
So there's this diversity of context in which the same image is being used.
So we want to exploit these two properties.
The redundancy of the image appearing multiple web pages and the diversity of the context in which they get used.
And bringing these together can enable you to get these snippets.
So the algorithm works in three phases, right?
One is the image that generation and then and then once you create this image sets, there is for each image that you can do a set of candidate snippets and then do a subset selection.

On the fly later.

the Super is relevant to that particular image and how interesting is that sniper to that image.
And once you have a collection of these snippets you also want them to be very diverse and we measure the diversity of the snippet collection using the entropy.
Because you have a free defined sort of vocabulary and you as you add more snippets of entropy.
Entropy is going to only go to go down OK.
So this diversity could be measured using entropy and one possible solution of solving this problem is just to come up with every possible combinations of snippets, subsets and then pick the best.
But that's not going to scale if you have a large number of candidates, but then you can resort to understanding that this function could.
It could be a submodular function.
What is a submodular function function which has diminishing returns as we add more snippets to the collection.

That maximizes this objective FK.

Our first baseman algorithm is Ecurie by image and webpage summarization.
The idea here is that you can find all occurrences of image on the web and then for each of those occurrences you can do a webpage summarization.

That we get and we use the same ranking as our ranking.

If you have a new input image and match it to the database and then transfer captions from the top matching ones.

Using webpage summarization.

Then what fraction of the time do we actually cover these?

Identify these snippets.
An foreign language we focus mainly on the English text and then we do it and then commercials on icons.

And it's sort of bringing down the single framework to combine multiple modalities or multiple multimedia content, and I think there's lots of interesting applications that we can build.
I showed you one, we have a couple of more in the paper and I think that there is.
Bringing in user and bringing in how user users these systems can also enrich how you create these applications on top.
Thank you very much.
